in_class_value: Afromontain rain forest with other forests and wetlands
in_class_description: Occurs as isolated remnants on mountain tops with a diverse ever green forests trees. This sort of forest also occurs along the banks of many rivers. Nevertheles these riverine forests are small and need particular protection.
in_class_description_detail: The forests have continuous but irregular crowns, little stratification, and are usually less than 20 m height. Typical Afromontane species are represented in Malawi by Apodytes dimidiata, Cassipourea gummiflua, Ficalhoa laurifolia, Maesa lanceolata. It is distributed through Misuku Hills, Nyika plateau, Vipsa, Ntchisi, Chongoni, Dedza, Mangochi, Zomba and Mulanje mountain forest reserves.
efg_description: These mountain rainforests are characterised by a single-layered tree canopy, with epiphytic ferns, bryophytes, lichens, orchids, and bromeliads draping tree branches. Grasses are rare or absent. At high altitude forest structure becomes less complex, with dwarf tree forms. Although rainfall is abundant (up to 6000 mm per year), productivity is limited by cool temperatures, wind exposure and shallow soils, although under the canopy a moist shady microclimate provides stable habitat for a frog, bird, plant and invertebrate species that are found nowhere else.

in_class_description: Lies above 1500 or 1600m having an excess of 50% Afromotane tree species ( Dowsett-Lemaire, Dowsett 2016). Afromontane rain forest is structurally similar to lowland Guineo-Congolian rain forest, whereas undifferentiated Afromontane forest is floristical.
in_class_description_detail: The Afromontane forests are floristically and structurally poorer with no emergents and genreally a much lower canopy with the height of the canopy usually being 25-45m and common species Entandrophrafma excelsum, Olea capensis. In Malawi tall luxuriant Afromontane rainforest is better developed in the north from the Misuku hills to Ntchisi mountain including the escarpments of the Nyika Plateau, Jembya plateau and some of the Vipya forest. In the south-central Malawi Afromonta
efg_description: These mountain rainforests are characterised by a single-layered tree canopy, with epiphytic ferns, bryophytes, lichens, orchids, and bromeliads draping tree branches. Grasses are rare or absent. At high altitude forest structure becomes less complex, with dwarf tree forms. Although rainfall is abundant (up to 6000 mm per year), productivity is limited by cool temperatures, wind exposure and shallow soils, although under the canopy a moist shady microclimate provides stable habitat for a frog, bird, plant and invertebrate species that are found nowhere else.

in_class_description: Miombo woodlands on hills and rocky outcrops of the central region, specific to Dzalanyama and Mchinji Forest Reserves and adjacent areas highly dominated by Brachystegia and Julbernadia tree species.
in_class_description_detail: Trees recorded are the miombo elements of Brachystegia bussei, B. manga, B. boehmii, B. spiciformis, Julbernardia globiflora, as well as Afzelia quanzensis, Diplorhynchus condylocarpon, Mimusops zeyheri, Oxytenanthera abyssinica, and Piliostigma thonning
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). Many plants have traits that promote tolerate of seasonal drought, such as deciduous leaf phenology, subterranean storage organs and deep roots. Invertebrate detritivores, notably termites, and vertebrate scavengers are key groups in the foodweb.

in_class_description: Bua and Dwanga Inshore Lake
in_class_description_detail: No further information
efg_description: Large volumes of permanent water in these lakes buffers water temperatures and effects of nutrient input on water quality. The spatial extent and range of habitats support very large numbers of species in some groups such as fish, some of which are unique to a single lake, often composed of closely related species, endemic to a lake. The high primary productivity from algae and aquatic plants lake supports diverse foodwebs. High numbers of plankton support large numbers of waterbugs, fish, frogs, reptiles, waterbirds, and mammals. Bacteria play key roles in cycling organic matter.

in_class_description: The Bua Catchment is divided into three distinct hydrological zones, based on topography namely: Plateau, steep slopes on the highland rising from the plateau and the rift valley escarpment and lakeshore plain.
in_class_description_detail: The drainage lines of Bua have dambo (seasonally wet grasslands) vegetation and groves of Syzigium (Judy Carter, 1985). Stream valleys contain marshy areas and stands of Raffia Palms. Fast flowing streams and rivers are fringed by strips of tall evergreen forest. The Bua Catchment Rivers is situated within coordinate bearing of 320˚35' and 340˚13'E Longitude and 120˚40' and 120˚55'S Latitude in the central region of Malawi. It has an area of approximately 10,654 km2  covering six districts which include Lilon.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: This ecosystem type includes both the seasonal and pereninial wetlands. They are present in the Mchinji Forest Reserve, Dzalamanya Forest reserve and Kasungu National park.
in_class_description_detail: The drainage lines of Bua have dambo (seasonally wet grasslands) vegetation and groves of Syzigium (Judy Carter, 1985). Stream valleys contain marshy areas and stands of Raffia Palms. Fast flowing streams and rivers are fringed by strips of tall evergreeen forest. These wetlands are present in Mchinji, Lilongwe, Kasungu, Dowa and Ntchisi.
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: From 50m to 700 m water depth is considered offshore.
in_class_description_detail: Availability of deeper water demersal fish species. Availability of pelagic spp e.g. Diplotaxodon, Copadichromis, Rhamphochromis and Engarulicypris spp. Sandy and rocky bottom. Very clean water. Higher wavelength. Low primary productivity.
efg_description: Large volumes of permanent water in these lakes buffers water temperatures and effects of nutrient input on water quality. The spatial extent and range of habitats support very large numbers of species in some groups such as fish, some of which are unique to a single lake, often composed of closely related species, endemic to a lake. The high primary productivity from algae and aquatic plants lake supports diverse foodwebs. High numbers of plankton support large numbers of waterbugs, fish, frogs, reptiles, waterbirds, and mammals. Bacteria play key roles in cycling organic matter.

in_class_description: Characterised by broad leaved trees relatively dry woodlands and intergrades to savanna consisting of Mopane woodlands, woodlands of fertile areas, thicket savannah of poorer areas, and woodland or savannah. Notes taken from Lengwe National.
in_class_description_detail: It is a mixed deciduous woodland with open canopy dominated by acacia, bouhinia and Combretum species. The occur on fertile soils on plateau and much of this woodland has been cleared for agricultutre. Disrtibuted across Ntcheu, Mwanza, Chikwawa, Balaka, Nsanje, Blantyre, Thyolo.

Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. in_class_description: Miombo woodland dominated by Brachystegia, Isoberlinia, Julbernardia species.
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by species of Brachystegia spp., Isoberlinia spp. and Julbernardia spp. Distributed from Southern Malawi in  Elephant marsh, Thyolo, Mulanje (bordering Mulanje mountain), Zomba  and Mwaza; and Central region in Mangochi, parts of Ntcheu, Dedza, Nkhotakota (Eastern side around Nkhotakota Game Reserve), Ntchisi
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). in_class_description: Dwangwa lies in the central part of the Lake Malawi, and is drained by representatives of the two main drainage systems, the Plateau System and the Rift Margin Consequent Rivers (Pike and Rimmington 1965)
in_class_description_detail: The natural vegetation is dominantly Brachystegia-Julbernardia woodland and includes the plateau, hill and scarp-foothill types (Kemp 1974). Covers 2 districts; Nkhotakota & Kasungu futher down to Kasungu National Park
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: These wetlands are a result of Dwangwa river which originates from Kasungu National Park. The wetlands are present Kasungu National park.
in_class_description_detail: The natural vegetation is dominantly Brachystegia-Julbernardia woodland and includes the plateau, hill and scarp-foothill types (Kemp 1974). The wetlands are present in Dwangwa and Kasungu
efg_description: Permanent marshes occur throughout tropical and temperate regions of the world in flat areas with stable water levels close to the surface. They are essentially treeless, with extensive reedbeds and aquatic grasses, interspersed with patches of open water. Food webs are strongly influenced by highly productive algae and plants, providing food for large numbers of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals.

in_class_description: Eastern Inlet Inshore Lake
in_class_description_detail: No further information

in_class_description: Grassland in with few shrubs at a river mouth or banks of water bodies
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by seasonal grassland with very few woody species. Distributed across the country along banks of large water bodies, flooded areas and river confluence.

in_class_description: Grassland with scattered or clustered woody species
in_class_description_detail: Characterised by grassess associated with berbs, shrubs and very few trees. Occurs in parts of vwaza, Mzuzu-Lunyangwa, western part of Mzimba boundary with Zambia, part of nkhotakota game reserve, part of Lake Chirwa wetlands and Terminaria cericea woodland in Phalombe

in_class_description: The ecosystem is composed of predominantly common reed Phragmites australis, bulrush Tyhpa domingensis, hippo grass Vossia cuspidata and papyrus sedge Cyperus papyrus. Invasive plants such as Water lettuce Pistia stratioites.
in_class_description_detail: This ecosystem type occurs in two district of Malawi namely Nsanje and  Chikwawa from  Chikwawa  Bridge  (upstream) to Chiromo Bridge (downstream).

They are essentially treeless, with extensive reedbeds and aquatic grasses, interspersed with patches of open water. Food webs are strongly influenced by highly productive algae and plants, providing food for large numbers of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals.

in_class_description: Constitutes three perrenial rivers and two small rivers that flow in Lake Malawi and an isolated stream in Nyika National Park.
in_class_description_detail: Largely covers Karonga district
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: The rivers are perennial and mostly flow through Nyika National Park and ultimately drain into Lake Malawi.
in_class_description_detail: They flow through montane grassland and afromontane forest.
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: This is shallow and vegetated area.
in_class_description_detail: Chambo (Oreochromis spp) are very common. Highly productive. Muddy bottom. Not very much affected by the southeasterly winds. The rivers flow through Karonga, Chitipa and Rumphi.
efg_description: Large volumes of permanent water in these lakes buffers water temperatures and effects of nutrient input on water quality. The spatial extent and range of habitats support very large numbers of species in some groups such as fish, some of which are unique to a single lake, often composed of closely related species, endemic to a lake. The high primary productivity from algae and aquatic plants lake supports diverse foodwebs. High numbers of plankton support large numbers of waterbugs, fish, frogs, reptiles, waterbirds, and mammals. Bacteria play key roles in cycling organic matter.

in_class_description: Lake Chilwa
in_class_description_detail: The majority of the lake is 2 to 3 meters deep. The lake is one third open water, one third marshes and swammps and one third floodplain glassland. It is situated in southern Malawi on the countries eastern border with Mozambique. The marsh and swamp areas extend into Mozambique where the open water areas are fully in Malawi.
efg_description: With a surface area of up to 100 km2, the diversity of small permanent lakes, ponds and pools depends on their size, depth and connectivity. Littoral vegetation and benthic energy pathways are critical to productivity and food web complexity. Deep lakes have plankton, supporting fish, birds and frogs, in different habitats of the lake. Shallow lakes are often more productive, providing breeding habitat for birds, frogs and reptiles, but limited buffering against nutrient inputs may result in regime shifts between alternative stable states dominated either by large aquatic plants or phytoplankton.

in_class_description: This type constitures the seven perennial rivers that flow into Lake Chilwa. However, there are numerous small seasonal streams as well that are part of this ecosystem type. Six of these rivers originate in Malawi.
in_class_description_detail: These rivers share a similarity in that they source from the highland ares that sorround the Lake. They come through montane vegetation areas, then run through open cannopy woodlands into the floodpplains to the main lake. The rivers are distributed in Machinga, Zomba and Phalombe.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: This ecosystem types included both the seasonal and perennial wetlands of sorrounding Lake Chilwa. Papyrus sp are the most dominat plant species in this type. Papyrus wetlands occur in deep, permanently inundated areas.
in_class_description_detail: Composed predominantly of Cyperus papyrus, with other Cyperus spp. and Phragmites reed beds. Vossia cuspidata and Echinochloa pyramidalis form floating mats on open water, with Pennisetum purpureum and Phragmites mauritianus more frequent at the edges. This ecosystem type is present in Machinga, Zomba and Phalombe areas. This type includes the wetlands around Mpoto Lagoon in Phalombe and extends into Mozambique as part of the Zambezian Papyrus wetland vegetation type.
efg_description: Permanent marshes occur throughout tropical and temperate regions of the world in flat areas with stable water levels close to the surface. They are essentially treeless, with extensive reedbeds and aquatic grasses, interspersed with patches of open water. Food webs are strongly influenced by highly productive algae and plants, providing food for large numbers of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals.

in_class_description: On the Malawian side, Lake Chiuta is fed by a number of seasonal streams that rise from its western highlands whose primary perennial source is Mpili River.
in_class_description_detail: No further information
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: Lake Chiuta Wetlands
in_class_description_detail: No further information

in_class_description: Lake Malombe is a tributary of Shire River, 30 KM long by 15 KM wide with a maximum depth of 5 m (Tweddle 1995).
in_class_description_detail: The lake is fed by the most eutrophic water in Lake Malawi, the southern east arm and enriched by streams flowing into the lake from its highly populated catchment area and by recycling of nutrients from sediments as a result of its shallowness. Located in the Mangochi and Machinga districts. It is located on the Shire River, in the Southern Region around 14°40′0″S 35°15′0″E, about 20 km (12 mi) south of Lake Malawi.
efg_description: With a surface area of up to 100 km2, the diversity of small permanent lakes, ponds and pools depends on their size, depth and connectivity. Littoral vegetation and benthic energy pathways are critical to productivity and food web complexity. Deep lakes have plankton, supporting fish, birds and frogs, in different habitats of the lake. Shallow lakes are often more productive, providing breeding habitat for birds, frogs and reptiles, but limited buffering against nutrient inputs may result in regime shifts between alternative stable states dominated either by large aquatic plants or phytoplankton.

in_class_description: These are woodlands sorrounding the eastern and western sides of Lake Malawi's Eastern arm.
in_class_description_detail: No further information

in_class_description: A basin with highly erosive soils dominated by Brachystegia/Isoberlinia/Julbernadia woodland in the forested areas and tall grass/scrub vegetation.
in_class_description_detail: Characterised by a basin with highly erodible soils dominated by Brachystegia/Isoberlinia/Julbernadia woodland in the forested areas and tall grass/scrub vegetation dominated by Hyparrhenia spp. and Phragmites spp. as well as Critically Endangered fish. Linthipe River originates from Dzalanyama Ranges (Dedza) and runs through Dedza, Lilongwe and Salima districts, before finally draining into lake Malawi.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: Mosaic of rooted swamp vegetation, floating vegetation and open water with grassy margins, seasonally inundated grassy floodplains, bordered by woodland.
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by graminoids (grasses, rushes, sedges and reeds) as the higher water table and poor drainage preclude most trees and shrubs while river banks are inhabited by a dense layer of shrubs and trees. Located in Lilongwe and Dedza

Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: This ecosystem previously dominated by Terminalia ciresia, is currently being taken over by Propsopis juliflora, an invasive plant, due to habitat alteration.
in_class_description_detail: The ecosystem is composed of small to medium sized deciduous trees of Terminalia sirecia and Propsopis juliflora, an invasive plant. The ecosystem is present in Chikwawa and Nsanje along the Shire River catchment area
efg_description: Permanent marshes occur throughout tropical and temperate regions of the world in flat areas with stable water levels close to the surface. They are essentially treeless, with extensive reedbeds and aquatic grasses, interspersed with patches of open water. Food webs are strongly influenced by highly productive algae and plants, providing food for large numbers of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals.

in_class_description: Wetlands along the Mwanza river running between Majete and Lengwe National Park. The flow within the North Zambezian undifferentiated woodland ecosystem type. Currently these are converted to agriculture.
in_class_description_detail: To be defined. Typical of the wetland in thicket /savanna. Located in Chikwawa district, gap area between Lengwe NP and Majete WR
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_value: Miombo woodland on hills and rocky outcrops
in_class_description: Miombo woodland dominated by species of genus Brachystegiain association with Isoberlinia angolensis, Julbernardia globiflora or Julbernardia paniculata
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by species of Brachystegia, either alone or with Isoberlinia angolensis, Julbernardia globiflora or J. paniculata. Extends all the way from Mua-Livulezi Forest Reserve in Dedza, through to Nkhotakota, Ntchisi, up to Chimaliro Forest Reserve.
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). Many plants have traits that promote tolerate of seasonal drought, such as deciduous leaf phenology, subterranean storage organs and deep roots. Invertebrate detritivores, notably termites, and vertebrate scavengers are key groups in the foodweb.

in_class_description: Afromontane evergreen bushland and thickets, with species of Erica and Vaccinium members of family Ericaceae as the most dominant species
in_class_description_detail: Lower slopes are mainly dominated by miombo woodlands with a few scattered groves of endangered Mulanje cedar ( Widdringtonia whytei). Located on Mulanje Mountain.
efg_description: Occurring on nutrient-deficient soils of tropical regions, these fire-prone shrublands and low forests are associated with dry tropical winters, often occurring in a matrix with savannas (T4.2) or tropical dry forests (T1.2). Dominated by small-leaved sclerophyll shrubs and grasses, plants have traits to capture and conserve nutrients, such as cluster roots and carnivorous forms. Birds, reptiles and seed-eating small mammals dominate the vertebrate fauna, with few vertebrate herbivores. Periodic fires are cues for life-history processes of plants and animals, and help maintain species composition and nutrient cycling.

in_class_description: Open woodlands that form mono stands of one species Colospermum mopane; they have diverse grasses asociated with it and a key provider of natural cavities for cavity dwelling species
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by C. mopane in association with Acacia nigrescens, Adansonia digitata (Baobab-Malambe), Combretum imberbe, Kirkia acuminata, Sclerocarya birrea (Marula). Located through Balaka- Phalula, Liwonde in Machinga district, Chingale in Zomba, Golomoti (Dedza), Makanjira, Cape Mclear (Mangochi), Lengwe National Park, Ngabu in Chikwawa, Vwaza Wildlife Game Reserve (e.g. Dowsett et al., 2006)
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). in_class_value: Mosaic of montane grassland and afromontane forest
in_class_description: Grassland rich in wildflowers with patches of tree species in clumps
in_class_description_detail: Extensive grassland of Nyika and Part of Viphya associated with tree species in patches. Exist in Viphya plateau and Nyika National Park.
efg_description: These mountain rainforests are characterised by a single-layered tree canopy, with epiphytic ferns, bryophytes, lichens, orchids, and bromeliads draping tree branches. Grasses are rare or absent. At high altitude forest structure becomes less complex, with dwarf tree forms. Although rainfall is abundant (up to 6000 mm per year), productivity is limited by cool temperatures, wind exposure and shallow soils, although under the canopy a moist shady microclimate provides stable habitat for a frog, bird, plant and invertebrate species that are found nowhere else.

in_class_description: Afromontane evergreen bushland and thickets.
in_class_description_detail: Afromontane evergreen bushland and thicket of Mulanje mountain vary in floristic composition, but species of the Erica Erica benguelensis, Erica nyassana, Erica astronyassana, Agauria salicifolia, Plectranthus dissectus and Vaccinium Ericaceae, Selago. Found on Mt. Mulanje on the plateau White (1983) 1600 to 2300 metres above sea level.
efg_description: Occurring on nutrient-deficient soils of tropical regions, these fire-prone shrublands and low forests are associated with dry tropical winters, often occurring in a matrix with savannas (T4.2) or tropical dry forests (T1.2). Dominated by small-leaved sclerophyll shrubs and grasses, plants have traits to capture and conserve nutrients, such as cluster roots and carnivorous forms. Birds, reptiles and seed-eating small mammals dominate the vertebrate fauna, with few vertebrate herbivores. Periodic fires are cues for life-history processes of plants and animals, and help maintain species composition and nutrient cycling.

in_class_description: Moist deciduous miombo woodland occurring in high-rainfall areas of the Mabu Plateau.
in_class_description_detail: The miombo woodlands are dominated by Brachystegia spiciformis, B. boehmii, B. longifolia, B. manga, B. utilis and Julbernardia globiflora. Other trees recorded are Acacia amythethophylla, A. goetzei subsp. goetzei and subsp. microphylla, A. polyacantha. Found on the lower slopes of Mulanje mountain,within Mulanje and Phalombe districts.  They exist at an altitude of 1500m, in areas of medium to high rainfall (Shorter 1999).
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). Many plants have traits that promote tolerate of seasonal drought, such as deciduous leaf phenology, subterranean storage organs and deep roots. Invertebrate detritivores, notably termites, and vertebrate scavengers are key groups in the foodweb.

in_class_description: A permanent freshwater marsh composed of Papyrus wetland that occur in deep, permanently inundated areas. This unit is often referred to as a marsh/dambo or wetland. The marsh begins at Nsanje and continues south to the southern tip of Malawi.
in_class_description_detail: Composed predominantly of Cyperus papyrus, with other Cyperus spp. and Phragmites reed beds. Vossia cuspidata and Echinochloa pyramidalis form floating mats on open water, with Pennisetum purpureum and Phragmites mauritianus more frequent at the edges. Permanently inundated wetland areas at low altitudes. The marsh begins at Nsanje and continues south to the southern tip of Malawi, there are several lagoons located in this wetland including Ndamera in the south western extremities.
efg_description: Permanent marshes occur throughout tropical and temperate regions of the world in flat areas with stable water levels close to the surface. They are essentially treeless, with extensive reedbeds and aquatic grasses, interspersed with patches of open water. Food webs are strongly influenced by highly productive algae and plants, providing food for large numbers of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals.

in_class_description: Nkhata Bay and Rumphi can be combined to describe the inshore. Nkhotakota and Salima can form central inshore area. Karonga should be different be different from the rest. It is a dominantly rocky and deep area.
in_class_description_detail: Opsaridium spp are common in most of the river mouth. Nutrient rich zone in the southern Nkhata Bay. Highly vegetated Nkhata Bay south and Nkhotakota north.
efg_description: Large volumes of permanent water in these lakes buffers water temperatures and effects of nutrient input on water quality. The spatial extent and range of habitats support very large numbers of species in some groups such as fish, some of which are unique to a single lake, often composed of closely related species, endemic to a lake. The high primary productivity from algae and aquatic plants lake supports diverse foodwebs. High numbers of plankton support large numbers of waterbugs, fish, frogs, reptiles, waterbirds, and mammals. Bacteria play key roles in cycling organic matter.

in_class_description: Open woodlands, grasslands, extensive plantations, marshes, wetland and dimba cultivation with a tropical wet and dry climate
in_class_description_detail: It is characterised by open woodlands, rain fed cultivation, open grasslands, plantations, marshes, wetland and dimba cultivation; Tropical wet and dry climate; Temperature: 21-24°C; Average annual rainfal 1621mm. Has xtensive tea and rubber plantations. The catchment is in northern Malawi and occupies the Dwambadzi, Mlowe and Usisya Lakeshores with the largest part located in Nkhata-Bay district. It is drained by Dwambadzi, Mlowe and Luweya Rivers, and a network of tributaries and minor rivers.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: Shallow lakes containig submerged and floating-leaved aquatic plants whereas deeper or turbid lakes normally contain emergent plants at the shoreline.
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by graminoids (grasses, rushes, sedges and reeds) as the higher water table and poor drainage preclude most trees and shrubs while river banks are inhabited by a dense layer of shrubs and trees. The riparian areas are characterised by zones of
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: Shallow and highly vegetated
in_class_description_detail: Oreochromis and other big cichlid fishes. Rich with birds. Confined to Nkhatabay.
efg_description: Large volumes of permanent water in these lakes buffers water temperatures and effects of nutrient input on water quality. The spatial extent and range of habitats support very large numbers of species in some groups such as fish, some of which are unique to a single lake, often composed of closely related species, endemic to a lake. The high primary productivity from algae and aquatic plants lake supports diverse foodwebs. High numbers of plankton support large numbers of waterbugs, fish, frogs, reptiles, waterbirds, and mammals. Bacteria play key roles in cycling organic matter.

in_class_description: It is largely drained by a network of riverine flows that include Kaombe, Lingadzi, Nkula, Lufuliza, Likoa, Rivers. Surface water flows are in a west-easterly direction, with many of the rivers deriving their headwaters from the western highlands.
in_class_description_detail: Nkhotakota Lakeshore Catchment Rivers consist of narrow strips of evergreen trees, growing on the banks water courses. Best example of this vegetation is preserved in Nkhotakota Wildlife Reserve (Dowsett et al 2006). The Nkhotakota Lakeshore catchment occupies the country’s central part of Africa’s Great Rift Valley where it is separated from the country’s Central African Plateau by escarpments in the uplands. It covers an area of 4,819 Km2.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. These are productive ecosystems with major energy and fine sediment inputs from floodplains and upper catchments. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: Permanent and/or intermitent freshwater marsh streching fom Nkhtakota to Salima.
in_class_description_detail: Characterised by grasses, rushes and sedges along the the Nkhotakota - Salima Lakeshore. Open grassland without dominant woody species. Restricted to Nkhotakota and salima at the very edge of Lake Malawi
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Typically, different plants respond to the mosaic of variable flooding regimes, supporting complex networks of invertebrates, waterbirds, reptiles, and mammals. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: The North Rukuru River has its sources from the Nyika Highlands and flows through the high plateau, and then cuts across the Karonga escarpment and the lakeshore region to discharge into Lake Malawi. Its Basin is 125km long and it forms a single river.
in_class_description_detail: Montane grassland covers most of the Nyika highlands, plateau and escarpment zones, with evergreen forest remnants in protected areas, mostly at the heads ofthe watercourses (Chafota et al, 2005). Present around the North  Rukuru  river, covering  an  area  of 2091km² originates  from  Nyika  Plateau  (2400m  high)  and  flows through thinly populated forest areas unit it opens out into broad valleys with a general elevation ranging 1000 – 1400 m.
efg_description: Lowland rivers with slow continuous flows up to 10,000m3/s are common at low elevations throughout tropical and temperate parts of the world. Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: Open grassland of Chitpa - Nyika National Park. sandy and very shallow over 20km stretch to the lake.
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by wetland grass and sedges without any woody species. Special for nyika national park and small part of Nthalire withing North Rukuru.
efg_description: Seasonal flooding and drying regimes characterise high productivity floodplain marshes in the seasonal tropics and subhumid temperate regions. Prey concentrate as the wetlands dry, and many plants and animals use specialised adaptations such as seed banks or egg banks, to survive drying.

in_class_description: Papyrus wetlands which occur in deep, permanently inundated areas.
in_class_description_detail: Permanently inundated wetland areas, domitated by members of genera; Cyperus, Phragmites ,Vossia, Echinochloa & Pennisetum spp.; pure grasslands to open Faidherbia /Acacia woodlands. Extends from  Nsanje, along Elephant Marsh and Majete.

in_class_description: The offshore should be split by region, thus southern, central and northern offshore. From 50m to 700 m water depth is considered offshore.
in_class_description_detail: Availability of deeper water demersal fish species. Availability of pelagic spp e.g. Diplotaxodon, Copadichromis, Rhamphochromis and Engarulicypris spp. Sandy and rocky bottom. Very clean water. Higher wavelength. Low primary productivity.

in_class_description: Open canopy forest woodland dominated by tree species.
in_class_description_detail: Characterised by Accacia polyacantha, Brachystegia Sp, Jubenadia Sp, Combretum Sp. Diploryncus condylocaparpon, Pseudo. maprouneifolia, Parinari curaterifolia, Pericopsis angolensis. Common in Namizimu, Mangochi, Liwonde national park, Zomba malosa, Chiradzulu and part of Mulanje forest reserve.

in_class_description: The Ruo river originates from Mulanje massif and it is the largest tributary of Shire river in southern Malawi. It is a collection of intermitent streams and rivers that flow into the river Ruo.
in_class_description_detail: The rivers originate from afro-montane grasslands at high altitudes, through open canopy woodlands. Associated plant species includes Newtonia buchananii, khaya anthotheca, Albizia versicolor, Brepnadia salicima amongst others. Rising on the slopes of the Mulanje mountain, it flows south to Mulanje town, where it veers southwest, forming 80 miles (130 km) of the Malaŵi-Mozambique border before entering the Shire River at Chiromo.

Zooplankton can be abundant, along with aquatic plants and diverse communities of fish able to tolerate a range of temperatures and oxygen concentrations, as well as reptiles, birds, and mammals that depend wholly or partly on lowland lotic aquatic habitats.

in_class_description: A collection of permanent and intermitent streams and rivers that empty into shire river.
in_class_description_detail: It consist of fresh water and associated plant species such as Steculia appendicula, Adansonia digitata, Teminaria cycamolous, Sebania sesbania , Higrophiluos grass and floating species. Most districts in the southern region such as Mangochi, Balaka, Machinga, Blantyre, Chikwawa, Thyolo, Mwanza and Nsanje.

in_class_description: These sandy areas stretch across Lake Malawi from south to north, all the way to the eastern part of Lake Malawi in Makanjila, Mangochi. Dominated by irrigation farming.
in_class_description_detail: No further information

in_class_description: The Songwe River is 165km long and has the total basin area of 1,890km². The Songwe River and its tributaries pass through three geomorphologic units; plateau, escarpment and lakeshore plain (Chafota et al, 2005).
in_class_description_detail: The Songwe catchment rivers occur in wet miombo forests dominated by Brachystegiais, afromontane forests dominated by Brachystegiaand Julbernardia, swamp dominated by Cyperus species, Typhaspecies, Vossia cuspidata, Pennisetum purpureum and Echinochloa. The Songwe catchment rivers area falls within both the territories of Malawi and Tanzania. The total area of the Songwe basin is 4,060 km² out of which 2,170 km2 is in Tanzania. The area that falls within Malawi is 1,890 km² (Chafota et al, 2005).

in_class_description: These are seasonal streams that flow into the Songwe river in the northen part of Malawi, Chitipa
in_class_description_detail: Occurs at Karonga district boardering Tanzania.

in_class_description: This ecosystem type includes rivers that drain into the south east arm of Lake Malawi from the eastern shore. The majority of the rivers are from the Namizimu forest reserve, while a few come from the Mozambique side.
in_class_description_detail: These rivers are characteristics of rivers passing through the dry miombo woodland type. These rivers are all in Mangochi District, Makanjira and Namizimu areas

in_class_description: The south Rukuru has its source in the central uplands of Malawi. The river is a perennial just like most of its tributatries. The tributaries include, Rumphi river, Mchenachena river Lunyangwa river, Mzimba river and Runyina river.

in_class_description_detail: These rivers have characteristics of rivers passing through dry miombo woodlands. The catchment rivers flow through Dedza, Salima, Mangochi and Ntcheu. They are present in several protected areas namely; Mchinji forest reserve, Kasungu National Park, and Dzalanyama Forest Reserve

in_class_description: Tall Miombo coincides with Open canopy woodland of hills & scarps.
in_class_description_detail: Permanently inundated wetland areas domitated by pure grasslands to open Faidherbia /Acacia woodlands. Extends from Songwe River, Mafinga Hills (Chitipa district) Northen Malawi, through Nyika National Park in Rumphi down to areas adjacent to Vwaza Game Reserve down to areas north of Mzuzu city.
efg_description: An unparalleled abundance and diversity of large herbivores maintain an open structure of these tree-grass ecosystems in the seasonal tropics of Africa and south Asia. Large herbivores are pivotal in maintaining short rhizomatous and tussock grasses, limiting recruitment of trees, cycling nutrients, sustaining complex food webs of invertebrate detritivores and diverse assemblages of mammalian and avian predators and scavengers. Seasonally high productivity coincides with the summer rainy season. Fires occur in some years, but are less influential than herbivores on ecosystem function. Trees and grasses have adaptations to seasonal drought and heavy browsing, such as rhizomes and stolons that allow grasses to spread under grazing pressure.

in_class_description: Occurs at lower altitudes approximately below 500m. Silver terminalia forms woodlands on sandy soils which are water logged during the wet season. The woodland is sometimes associated with mixed species, particularly Acacia (Vachelia) and Combretum.
in_class_description_detail: The woodland is dominated by Terminalia sericea (Silver Terminalia) and sometimes with other species present such as Acacia xanthophloea (Yellow-barked Acacia) and Brachystegia boehmii. Extends from Machinga, Zomba, Phalombe, Chiradzulu and isolated population in Salima. It used to dominate the Phalombe and Kawinga plains around lake Chirwa and the area west of lake Chiuta
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). in_class_description: Physiognomically intermediate between woodland and forests; Floristically a mixture of forest and woodland species (http://www.sdnp.org.mw/enviro/soe_report/box_7_1.html)
in_class_description_detail: Dominated by species of Brachystegia growing in association with Julbernardia and Isoberlinia within montane grassland and shrubland. Runs from North West Chitipa to Nkhatabay and then along the eastern part of Kaningina Forest Reserve and is dominant around South Viphya Forest Reserve
efg_description: An unparalleled abundance and diversity of large herbivores maintain an open structure of these tree-grass ecosystems in the seasonal tropics of Africa and south Asia. in_class_description: This is an important wetland habitat.
in_class_description_detail: No further information

in_class_description: Moist deciduous miombo woodland above 1000 m in elevation.
in_class_description_detail: The trees are dominated by miombo species Brachystegia spiciformis, B. longifolia, B. stipulata, B. floribunda, B. utilis, Julbernardia globiflora, and J. paniculata, with the addition of Anisophyllea boehmii, Bersama abyssinica subsp. engleriana, Fagaro. Stretched from central to northen Malawi covering wet open woodlands of Dedza to Karonga. These woodlands extend to north-western corner of Mozambique, along the Angonia Plateau between Zambia and Malawi (Tete Province).
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). Many plants have traits that promote tolerate of seasonal drought, such as deciduous leaf phenology, subterranean storage organs and deep roots. in_class_description: Dry open canopy woodland dominated by Brachystegia and Julbernardia spp
in_class_description_detail: The trees are deciduous but lose their leaves only for a short period. The branches and leaves do not touch one another and sufficient light can reach allowing grass to grow. Located in most parts of Mangochi, Balaka and slightly on the eastern part of Ntchewu
efg_description: In pyric savannas, recurring fire is the principal agent that limits tree dominance and maintains tree-grass coexistence. Dominated by tussock grasses that grow tall during high-productivity wet summers and cure over dry winter seasons, these ecosystems occur on all major land masses at tropical and subtropical latitudes around the world. Large mammalian herbivores are usually present, but not at densities that limit grass growth or mediate tree-grass coexistence (unlike T4.1). in_class_description: Zanzibar-Inhambane transitional lowland rain forest
in_class_description_detail: No further information
efg_description: A huge diversity of species occupy niches within a complex vertically-layered structure of plant forms. High productivity is fuelled by rapid-growing plants including buttressed trees, bamboos, epiphytes, lianas and ferns. Forest canopies sustain moist soils and abundant leaf litter decomposed by fungi and bacteria. High diversity of invertebrates at all levels of the forest supports diverse vertebrate life forms, particularly mammals and birds, which play critical roles in plant dispersal and pollination. Conditions near the equator are stable and humid year-round (up to 6000 mm rain per annum), but become more seasonal with mild winter frosts in the subtropics.

in_class_description: Zanzibar-Inhambane transitional rain forest
in_class_description_detail: Found on Mulanje Mountain and Michese Forest Reserve
efg_description: These mountain rainforests are characterised by a single-layered tree canopy, with epiphytic ferns, bryophytes, lichens, orchids, and bromeliads draping tree branches. Grasses are rare or absent. At high altitude forest structure becomes less complex, with dwarf tree forms. Although rainfall is abundant (up to 6000 mm per year), productivity is limited by cool temperatures, wind exposure and shallow soils, although under the canopy a moist shady microclimate provides stable habitat for a frog, bird, plant and invertebrate species that are found nowhere else.
